title: How to Grill Duck Breast

steps.headline: Sear the duck breast in a pan first if it has fat.
steps.description: Duck breast with lots of fat in it can cause flare-ups while grilling, which can be dangerous. By scoring the skin and cooking the duck breast in a pan for a few minutes, you allow the fat to be released in a safer environment. Most store-bought duck breast will have fat.

steps.headline: Score the skin of the duck breast to help remove the fat.
steps.description: Take a clean knife and create shallow cuts in the skin of the duck breast about 0.25 inches (0.64 cm) apart from one another. Turn the duck breast 90 degrees and create more cuts so that you’ve created a crisscross pattern. Only cut the skin, not the actual meat—cuts should just be on the top layer. Since the fat is under the skin, scoring the skin helps the fat be released.

steps.headline: Season your duck breast, if desired.
steps.description: Pat down the duck breast with a clean paper towel to remove any excess moisture. Season both sides of the duck breast evenly using your choice of seasoning. Salt and pepper are commonly used to season duck breast, or you can use a store-bought special seasoning.

steps.headline: Set the stove to medium-low heat.
steps.description: You don't need to be fully cooking the duck breast yet—just heating it up enough for the fat to drain out. Turn on the stove before placing the duck breast in the pan. The pan should be at roughly 325 °F (163 °C).

steps.headline: Place the duck breast skin-side down in a nonstick pan.
steps.description: You want the scored side of the duck breast to be the one being seared. Use a nonstick pan to keep the duck breast from sticking. Cook the duck breast for 10 minutes.

parts.name: Finishing the Breast on the Grill

steps.headline: Clean and oil the grate to prevent the duck breast from sticking.
steps.description: Wipe off any old residue using a grate scraper or paper towel, if necessary. Coat the rack with oil using a paper towel so that the duck breast won't stick to the grate. You can also spray the grill rack with cooking spray, but the grill can't be warm or turned on when you do this because the can is flammable. Use oils such as canola, peanut, soy, or corn.

steps.headline: Set up a hot side and cool side of the grill.
steps.description: Turn one side on so that it’s set to medium-high, and the other side so that it’s on low-medium. Do this before starting to grill so that the grill has time to heat up. Give the grill roughly 5 minutes to preheat. If you're using a charcoal grill, set it up so that the coals are on 1 side, creating 2 different zones of heat. If you're cooking super small duck breasts, they may be completely done cooking after only being on the hot side of the grill.

steps.headline: Move the duck breast from the pan to the hot side of the grill.
steps.description: If you didn’t sear the skin first, simply put the duck breast right on the grill. Place it skin-side down and grill it for 5-7 minutes, or until the skin is browned. The skin should also be slightly crispy.

steps.headline: Flip the duck breast over to grill for 2-3 more minutes.
steps.description: Use tongs to turn over the duck breast so that the other side gets a chance to cook. If desired, you can coat the duck breast with a sauce or glaze before flipping it, and then coat it again once you move it to the cool side.

steps.headline: Switch the duck breast to the cooler side of the grill.
steps.description: Smaller duck breasts will be done at this point, but larger ones might not be. Let the duck breast continue to cook on the cooler side of the grill until completely cooked. The internal temperature should be about 130 °F (54 °C). You can check the internal temperature using a meat thermometer. If you don’t have a meat thermometer, do a simple touch test. If the duck breast feels like your forehead does when you touch it, it’s well done. If it feels like your cheek, it’s rare. Avoid cutting into the duck breast—it needs to sit for at least 5 minutes after it's done cooking while it's still completely intact.

steps.headline: Let the duck breast sit for at least 5 minutes before cutting it.
steps.description: Move the duck breast to a plate after it’s done grilling, placing it skin-side up and uncovered. Wait 5-10 minutes  before slicing it open with a sharp knife and beginning to eat. Letting the duck breast sit for awhile before cutting it will help distribute the temperature evenly and spread the moisture around.

steps.headline: Sprinkle your duck breast with salt and pepper for a simple seasoning.
steps.description: This will give your duck breast ample flavor and doesn’t require any special ingredients. Sprinkle some salt and pepper on both sides of the duck breast and it’s ready to go. How much salt and pepper you use will depend on your personal preferences.

steps.headline: Marinade the duck breast for a couple hours before grilling.
steps.description: If you have a marinade that you like to use, place your duck breast in a plastic sealable bag and pour in enough marinade to cover the duck breast. Let it marinade for 2 hours before starting to grill.

steps.headline: Rub a seasoning onto the duck breast for unique flavors.
steps.description: There are tons of different seasonings and spices that you can try out on your duck breast. Rub the seasoning into the duck breast thoroughly, coating both sides before grilling. Choose a store-bought spice blend that you like, or create your own seasoning at home.

steps.headline: Spread barbecue sauce onto the duck breast for a quick fix.
steps.description: Use your favorite store-bought barbecue sauce, or you can make your own! Use a pastry brush or spoon to cover the duck breast in as much barbecue sauce as you’d like. You can coat the duck breast before grilling as well as during grilling.

steps.headline: Create a pineapple honey glaze to spread on your duck breast.
steps.description: Mix together 0.5 cups (120 ml) unsweetened pineapple juice and 0.25 cups (59 ml) of honey. Cook them in a pan over medium heat until they turn into a syrup. Add 0.5 teaspoons (2.5 ml) of fresh ginger and 1.5 teaspoons (7.4 ml) of minced jalapeno chiles and let it simmer for 2 minutes. Brush this on the duck breast while it’s still cooking.

text: Searing the Duck Breast Sear the duck breast in a pan first if it has fat. Duck breast with lots of fat in it can cause flare-ups while grilling, which can be dangerous. By scoring the skin and cooking the duck breast in a pan for a few minutes, you allow the fat to be released in a safer environment. Most store-bought duck breast will have fat. Score the skin of the duck breast to help remove the fat. Take a clean knife and create shallow cuts in the skin of the duck breast about 0.25 inches (0.64 cm) apart from one another. Turn the duck breast 90 degrees and create more cuts so that you’ve created a crisscross pattern. Only cut the skin, not the actual meat—cuts should just be on the top layer. Since the fat is under the skin, scoring the skin helps the fat be released. Season your duck breast, if desired. Pat down the duck breast with a clean paper towel to remove any excess moisture. Season both sides of the duck breast evenly using your choice of seasoning. Salt and pepper are commonly used to season duck breast, or you can use a store-bought special seasoning. Set the stove to medium-low heat. You don't need to be fully cooking the duck breast yet—just heating it up enough for the fat to drain out. Turn on the stove before placing the duck breast in the pan. The pan should be at roughly 325 °F (163 °C). Place the duck breast skin-side down in a nonstick pan. You want the scored side of the duck breast to be the one being seared. Use a nonstick pan to keep the duck breast from sticking. Cook the duck breast for 10 minutes. Finishing the Breast on the Grill Clean and oil the grate to prevent the duck breast from sticking. Wipe off any old residue using a grate scraper or paper towel, if necessary. Coat the rack with oil using a paper towel so that the duck breast won't stick to the grate. You can also spray the grill rack with cooking spray, but the grill can't be warm or turned on when you do this because the can is flammable. Use oils such as canola, peanut, soy, or corn. Set up a hot side and cool side of the grill. Turn one side on so that it’s set to medium-high, and the other side so that it’s on low-medium. Do this before starting to grill so that the grill has time to heat up. Give the grill roughly 5 minutes to preheat. If you're using a charcoal grill, set it up so that the coals are on 1 side, creating 2 different zones of heat. If you're cooking super small duck breasts, they may be completely done cooking after only being on the hot side of the grill. Move the duck breast from the pan to the hot side of the grill. If you didn’t sear the skin first, simply put the duck breast right on the grill. Place it skin-side down and grill it for 5-7 minutes, or until the skin is browned. The skin should also be slightly crispy. Flip the duck breast over to grill for 2-3 more minutes. Use tongs to turn over the duck breast so that the other side gets a chance to cook. If desired, you can coat the duck breast with a sauce or glaze before flipping it, and then coat it again once you move it to the cool side. Switch the duck breast to the cooler side of the grill. Smaller duck breasts will be done at this point, but larger ones might not be. Let the duck breast continue to cook on the cooler side of the grill until completely cooked. The internal temperature should be about 130 °F (54 °C). You can check the internal temperature using a meat thermometer. If you don’t have a meat thermometer, do a simple touch test. If the duck breast feels like your forehead does when you touch it, it’s well done. If it feels like your cheek, it’s rare. Avoid cutting into the duck breast—it needs to sit for at least 5 minutes after it's done cooking while it's still completely intact. Let the duck breast sit for at least 5 minutes before cutting it. Move the duck breast to a plate after it’s done grilling, placing it skin-side up and uncovered. Wait 5-10 minutes  before slicing it open with a sharp knife and beginning to eat. Letting the duck breast sit for awhile before cutting it will help distribute the temperature evenly and spread the moisture around. Creating Different Flavors Sprinkle your duck breast with salt and pepper for a simple seasoning. This will give your duck breast ample flavor and doesn’t require any special ingredients. Sprinkle some salt and pepper on both sides of the duck breast and it’s ready to go. How much salt and pepper you use will depend on your personal preferences. Marinade the duck breast for a couple hours before grilling. If you have a marinade that you like to use, place your duck breast in a plastic sealable bag and pour in enough marinade to cover the duck breast. Let it marinade for 2 hours before starting to grill. Rub a seasoning onto the duck breast for unique flavors. There are tons of different seasonings and spices that you can try out on your duck breast. Rub the seasoning into the duck breast thoroughly, coating both sides before grilling. Choose a store-bought spice blend that you like, or create your own seasoning at home. Spread barbecue sauce onto the duck breast for a quick fix. Use your favorite store-bought barbecue sauce, or you can make your own! Use a pastry brush or spoon to cover the duck breast in as much barbecue sauce as you’d like. You can coat the duck breast before grilling as well as during grilling. Create a pineapple honey glaze to spread on your duck breast. Mix together 0.5 cups (120 ml) unsweetened pineapple juice and 0.25 cups (59 ml) of honey. Cook them in a pan over medium heat until they turn into a syrup. Add 0.5 teaspoons (2.5 ml) of fresh ginger and 1.5 teaspoons (7.4 ml) of minced jalapeno chiles and let it simmer for 2 minutes. Brush this on the duck breast while it’s still cooking.
